story:
OUR CAMPAIGN HAS ENDED BUT YOU CAN STILL SUPPORT ASYMPTOTE AT OUR DONATE PAGE HERE. 

 

 

Goethe thought world literature important not as a mere cultural product but because it could "foster the true progress of mankind." Support Asymptote so that we can continue to back the translators who bring us world literature.

 

 

 

 “Magnificent.”

-- David Mitchell, author of Cloud Atlas

Asymptote is an online journal dedicated to bringing together the best in contemporary literature. Our mission is simple: to unlock the literary treasures of the world.

To date we’ve published authors working in 54 languages and coming from 75 different countries. These include familiar names (Haruki Murakami, Ruth Padel, Lydia Davis) and Nobel Prize winners (Imre Kertész, Czeslaw Milosz, José Saramago). We also bring you the work of great international writers who are only just beginning to be translated into English: these include Abdellah Taïa (2010 Prix de Flore), Jonas Hassen Khemiri (Obie Award, 2011) and Toh EnJoe (Akutagawa Prize, 2012).

We host poetry, fiction, drama, non-fiction, visual art, literary criticism, and interviews, and we even have a special section for essays in which overlooked non-English writers are concisely introduced. For instance, Mary Gaitskill wrote an essay for us on the Japanese crime writer Natsuo Kirino, which we then commissioned to be translated into Japanese so that Japanese readers could read it right next to the English original.

However, most of our work is in English translation, presented together with the source texts. Wherever possible we also host MP3 recordings of the original, so that our readers can experience not just the look of the original language but also the way it sounds.

 


 “When I’m not busy saving ships from certain disaster, I’m usually translating for Asymptote Journal”.

-- Reif Larsen, author of The Selected Works of T. S. Spivet

Who We Are

Asymptote is run by a team of international editors across three continents, many of whom are translators themselves. (In fact one of our own, Howard Goldblatt, is the translator of the recent Nobel Laureate Mo Yan.) Though we don’t share a single physical office, our geographical spread gives us a breathtaking reach: we can pull the best new and undiscovered writers from every place that we are to present in our pages, issue after issue.

My name is Lee Yew Leong, and I’m Asymptote’s Taiwan-based Singaporean Editor-in-Chief. Also associated with many countries are our drama editor, Obie Award-winning Caridad Svich, born in the US to Cuban-Argentine-Spanish-Croatian parents, and our visual editor, acclaimed British visual artist Simon Morley based in South Korea.




“An almost unbelievably good international magazine.”

-- Forrest Gander, Pulitzer Prize Finalist 2012, National Book Critics Circle Finalist 2011

What We’ll Do With Your Money

As we enter our third year as a free online magazine, we are finding it difficult to continue delivering the best contemporary writing from around the world while still remaining completely volunteer-based. Our team has expanded to more than 30 people, and we need to turn semi-professional in order to coordinate all our efforts. We’ll also use the money we raise for the following purposes:

-- to hold a new international translation contest (to be judged by contributing editor Howard Goldblatt together with Eliot Weinberger, the esteemed essayist and translator of Octavio Paz, Bei Dao, and Jorge Luis Borges);

-- to partner with local literary journals around the world (such as Unitas in Taiwan, which has already worked with us to publish our recent "Sinophone 20 under 40" feature and to introduce the work of our contributor, the Lebanese author Dominique Eddé, to Chinese readers in its September 2012 issue);  

-- to invest in farther-reaching publicity, so that our authors can reach even more readers;

-- to host more events and workshops around the globe (we began doing this in January, with a series of events in nine different cities around the world including New York, Barcelona, and Beijing);

-- and to fund, one day, our very own publishing arm.

 

What You’ll Get

By contributing to our cause, you will not only be supporting writing across linguistic and political borders, but you’ll also receive a range of our special rewards—limited-edition postcards, tote bags, unique "Famous First Lines" posters, art prints, and signed books—as evidence of our deep gratitude. We hope you have enjoyed the hard work we have put into the magazine over the past two years.

Support us by donating whatever amount you can spare or by spreading the word about Asymptote and our campaign. Help us to continue our mission in years to come!

 

Our most sincere thanks from Taipei, Berlin, Nijmegen, London, New York, St. Louis, Singapore, Seoul, Shizuoka, Padova, Philadelphia, Beijing, South Bend, Boulder, Ann Arbor, and Bergen.
story_txt:
OUR CAMPAIGN HAS ENDED BUT YOU CAN STILL SUPPORT ASYMPTOTE AT OUR DONATE PAGE HERE. 
 
 
Goethe thought world literature important not as a mere cultural product but because it could "foster the true progress of mankind." Support Asymptote so that we can continue to back the translators who bring us world literature.
 
 
 
 “Magnificent.”
-- David Mitchell, author of Cloud AtlasAsymptote is an online journal dedicated to bringing together the best in contemporary literature. Our mission is simple: to unlock the literary treasures of the world. 
To date we’ve published authors working in 54 languages and coming from 75 different countries. These include familiar names (Haruki Murakami, Ruth Padel, Lydia Davis) and Nobel Prize winners (Imre Kertész, Czeslaw Milosz, José Saramago). We also bring you the work of great international writers who are only just beginning to be translated into English: these include Abdellah Taïa (2010 Prix de Flore), Jonas Hassen Khemiri (Obie Award, 2011) and Toh EnJoe (Akutagawa Prize, 2012).
We host poetry, fiction, drama, non-fiction, visual art, literary criticism, and interviews, and we even have a special section for essays in which overlooked non-English writers are concisely introduced. For instance, Mary Gaitskill wrote an essay for us on the Japanese crime writer Natsuo Kirino, which we then commissioned to be translated into Japanese so that Japanese readers could read it right next to the English original.
However, most of our work is in English translation, presented together with the source texts. Wherever possible we also host MP3 recordings of the original, so that our readers can experience not just the look of the original language but also the way it sounds.
 

 “When I’m not busy saving ships from certain disaster, I’m usually translating for Asymptote Journal”.
-- Reif Larsen, author of The Selected Works of T. S. Spivet
Who We Are
Asymptote is run by a team of international editors across three continents, many of whom are translators themselves. (In fact one of our own, Howard Goldblatt, is the translator of the recent Nobel Laureate Mo Yan.) Though we don’t share a single physical office, our geographical spread gives us a breathtaking reach: we can pull the best new and undiscovered writers from every place that we are to present in our pages, issue after issue.
My name is Lee Yew Leong, and I’m Asymptote’s Taiwan-based Singaporean Editor-in-Chief. Also associated with many countries are our drama editor, Obie Award-winning Caridad Svich, born in the US to Cuban-Argentine-Spanish-Croatian parents, and our visual editor, acclaimed British visual artist Simon Morley based in South Korea.

“An almost unbelievably good international magazine.”
-- Forrest Gander, Pulitzer Prize Finalist 2012, National Book Critics Circle Finalist 2011
What We’ll Do With Your Money
As we enter our third year as a free online magazine, we are finding it difficult to continue delivering the best contemporary writing from around the world while still remaining completely volunteer-based. Our team has expanded to more than 30 people, and we need to turn semi-professional in order to coordinate all our efforts. We’ll also use the money we raise for the following purposes:
-- to hold a new international translation contest (to be judged by contributing editor Howard Goldblatt together with Eliot Weinberger, the esteemed essayist and translator of Octavio Paz, Bei Dao, and Jorge Luis Borges);
-- to partner with local literary journals around the world (such as Unitas in Taiwan, which has already worked with us to publish our recent "Sinophone 20 under 40" feature and to introduce the work of our contributor, the Lebanese author Dominique Eddé, to Chinese readers in its September 2012 issue);  
-- to invest in farther-reaching publicity, so that our authors can reach even more readers;
-- to host more events and workshops around the globe (we began doing this in January, with a series of events in nine different cities around the world including New York, Barcelona, and Beijing);
-- and to fund, one day, our very own publishing arm.
 

What You’ll Get
By contributing to our cause, you will not only be supporting writing across linguistic and political borders, but you’ll also receive a range of our special rewards—limited-edition postcards, tote bags, unique "Famous First Lines" posters, art prints, and signed books—as evidence of our deep gratitude. We hope you have enjoyed the hard work we have put into the magazine over the past two years. 
Support us by donating whatever amount you can spare or by spreading the word about Asymptote and our campaign. Help us to continue our mission in years to come!
 

Our most sincere thanks from Taipei, Berlin, Nijmegen, London, New York, St. Louis, Singapore, Seoul, Shizuoka, Padova, Philadelphia, Beijing, South Bend, Boulder, Ann Arbor, and Bergen.

story:
All progress on the expedition preparations and vehicle build shall be narrated at www.thiseuropeanlife.com.

 

How did it start?

My name is Miguel and I have a serious case of the travel bug! Ever since graduation from the Rhode Island School of Design in 2011, I started writing a blog called "This European Life", in which I narrate all kinds of experiences and thoughts I come across in my travels, mainly road-based. I liked the nomad lifestyle so much, I internet for half a year at a mechanical workshop, Burlingame Motors, where I learned how to maintain and diagnose my own car as a step towards self-sufficiency when traveling.

This time around, with the little I have, I will be preparing for the mother of all road trips: the PanAmerican Highway, starting on August 18th in the little town of North Wales, Pennsylvania. From there, I shall embark on a one-year expedition across the American continent, volunteering for several non-profits in several countries, and documenting everything I find in the way to my final destination, Tierra del Fuego.

I will mainly write prose (diary-based) and poetry, take plenty of pictures of my progress, and take some video when circumstances allow it; publishing it online as I move across the land –obviously, when internet is available. Part of this media will be devoted to you, so keep on reading to see what perks you will get!

Cost and expenses

I budgeted this one year of travel at $23,942, here is how its broken apart:

  • $1,500 for the vehicle, a 1981 Mercedes wagon with the bullet-proof turbodiesel engine; an excellent combination of mechanical simplicity, fuel economy and durable construction.
  • $2,500 for any mechanical work / parts throughout the journey, starting with some modifications in the US. Obviously, having bought it at auction, it needs some work; mainly suspension upgrades to handle the feared bumps in the roads of Latin America, and some fabrication (brush guard, winch) to turn it into a perfectly capable expedition vehicle.
  • $1,600 in camera equipment. I plan on taking a Canon 60D, which is said to be an excellent platform, as well as a more portable point-and-shoot camera that is a little more discreet. This includes cards and all paraphernalia.
  • $1,250 in other equipment, mainly hard drives and computer and camera accesories to be able to keep and store all the media that I take on the way.
  • $750 in tools (wrenches, screwdrivers, jacks) and spares (belts, fuel filters), just in case. I have some tools of my own and can take care of small issues. 
  • $3,625 in fuel, assuming the trip will be 20,000 miles at 24-25mpg.
  • $2,335 in border crossings, including passport stamping and the costly –yet unavoidable- container shipping at the Darien Gap (Panama to Colombia).
  • $1,512 in insurance, for myself (Nomad Health Insurance) and the car.
  • $935 in lodging, when I am not sleeping in my own car or it is not possible or safe to do so. Keep in mind, this is a year's worth of travel!
  • $3,750 for food and supplies (detergent, soap, medications just in case).
  • $3,270 in miscellaneous expenses, such as overlanding equipment (stove, roof tent, jerrycans for fuel and water...) and road "surprises" (breakdowns).
  • $900 for any fees charged by Indiegogo and Uncle Sam.

From these $24,000 I would like to ask for 1/2 of that amount, $12,000. If I get over this amount, I will make some small changes to the route and make it more diverse –a visit to Uruguay/Paraguay, for example.

The Perks!

Obviously, you need to get something in exchange. Depending in the amount you donate, the perk will be different; however, all perks are guaranteed exclusive access to a private, password-protected photo album in Photobucket.

  • $1: a wholehearted thank you, and access to the online photo album.
  • $5: a personalized email + Online photo album.
  • $10: a postcard from the country of your choice + Online photo album.
  • $20: a "doodle card" from the country of your choice + Online photo album.
  • $50: a "doddle letter" from the country of your choice + Online photo album.
  • $75: an original, written, large format "photo-card" + Online photo album.
  • $100: a printed book with select pictures and quotes + Online photo album.
  • $200: an acrylic/watercolor picture from any country + Online album.

Now, if you have a business you want to promote, I am renting body panels on my expedition vehicle to feature some publicity. Any of these perks is valid for one year, yet it does not cover the costs of making/installing the advertisement wraps:

  • $500: medium advertisement wrap on one body panel + Online album.
  • $1000: a full body panel + Online photo album.

And now, the MOTHERLOAD: if you organize a public/private talk about the journey, its preparations, artmaking, or the simple secret of doing what you like in life. These talks include basic air transportation; contact me before bidding on one of these.

  • $1,500: one-day talk/workshop in the US before I depart.
  • $5,000: talk and workshop ANYWHERE ELSE in the world after the trip.
  • $?????: Hire me after the trip as an artist or as a travel writer.

Choose one perk or choose several! I am definitely open to the possibility of creating personalized packages to write to you from EVERY country in the route!

The Impact

The volunteering element is just as important as all the art-making process. I strongly believe that strong life experiences should carry an element of social responsibility, as no human being is complete without his/her surroundings. These are some of the functions that I will be undertaking in the non-profits along the way...

  • Teacher (art, English, Spanish) for children from rough backgrounds.
  • Builder of shelters and homes in communties.
  • Researcher for environmental projects in Central America.
  • Engineer for sustainable machinery that will empower impoverished villages.
  • Mechanic... as I am sure someone will need a quick fix along the way.

I have experience volunteering in two different countries: Mexico (Door of Faith Orphanage) and Guatemala (Partners in Development, home building); these two experiences have made me come back for more!

Other Ways You Can Help

In this economy I would not be surprised to see that your wallet is empty... no problem! There are many other ways you can still help!

  • Facebook/Twitter the living heck out of this project!
  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this expedition!
  • Find any sponsors that can provide materials / supplies for the expedition and the communities that I visit. I will be most glad to give them free publicity!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Lynn Gehl and I am Algonquin Anishinaabe-kwe from the Ottawa River Valley Canada.  I have been working for over 25 years on my section 15 Charter challenge.  Although Canada has the Charter of Rights and Freedoms which states we have the right to live free from sex discrimination I, and many other people, are not afforded this right.

Although the Indian Act was amended in 1985 and 2011 to remove the sex discrimination, all of the sex discrimination was not removed while additional sex discrimination was created.  In this way, these amendments are best understood as failed remedial legislation.

Since 1985, through Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada's (AANDC) "unstated" paternity policy, Canada discriminates against Indigenous people when their father's signature is not ascribed to their birth certificate. More particularly, what happens in these situations is that AANDC assumes the father is a non-Indian, where as a result many children born to mothers registered under section 6(2) of the Indian Act are denied Indian status and thus their treaty rights, First Nation band membership, First Nation citizenship, and are marginalized in the land claims and self-government process. 

Disturbingly, this policy of denial remains in place in situations of incest, rape, gang rape, sexual slavery, and prostitution.

Help me help mothers and children end this sex discrimination.  Your support through purchasing my book - one book or a book bundle - titled "Mkadengwe: Sharing Canada's Colonial Process through Black Face Methodology" will help me continue forward with my movement.

All discriminations - sexism, racism, and ableism - are connected.  No one is free until the most oppressed is free.  By standing behind this effort you will be working to liberate yourself as well.

To learn more see www.lynngehl.com I have many resources through my website as well as quick links on the front page.

Here are 2 rabble articles:

http://rabble.ca/news/2013/04/indian-act-legislative-silence-and-ongoing-sex-discrimination-canada

http://rabble.ca/news/2013/01/canadas-unstated-paternity-policy-amounts-cultural-genocide-against-indigenous-children


What We Need & What You Get

The funds raised through this campaign will be directed toward my expenses taking my Charter challenge to court.  My court date is October 20th through 22nd. This matter will be heard in the Ontario Superior Court of Justice in Toronto.   

Funding will also be directed toward the creation of additional academic and community resources such as publishing in venues such as rabble and Canadian Dimension, and my personal website.  I will also continue to make grassroots videos and posters.

Through purchasing one, two, five, or ten of my books you will have direct access to learning about and understanding Canada's colonial history from an Indigenous perspective and through an Indigenous way of knowing.

While my book retails for $17.95: http://www.lynngehl.com/my-3rd-book-mkadengwe.html - I am letting them go through this venue for the price of $15.00 plus shipping.

While one book is available for:

$15.00 plus shipping ($5.00) = $20.00.

You save $2.95.

Two books are available for:

$28.00 plus shipping ($10.00) = $38.00.

You save $7.90.

Five books are available for:

$65.00 plus shipping ($15.00) = $80.00.

You save $24.75.

Ten books are available for:

$120.00 plus shipping ($20.00) = $140.00.

You save $59.50.

Remember, these books retail for $17.95 each.  By supporting this campaign you help my Charter challenge, as well as gain from by purchasing the book at the lower price/s.

I will sign a copy or all copies upon request.  Email me immediately after you make your contribution at lynngehl@gmail.com

The Impact

The most impacted by AANDC's unstated paternity policy are young mothers and their babies.  This is particularly the situation with young mothers located in northern First Nation communities.  These young mothers and babies are dependent on the health care and education rights that are associated with Indian status and treaty rights.  It is unconscionable that Canada would be targeting mothers and babies in their need to eliminate the treaty responsibilities that this country is founded on.

Indigenous women have been doing their part to eliminate this sex discrimination yet Canada - who has the deep pockets to eliminate this sex discrimination - has opted to disguise and create new forms of sex discrimination.

Your contribution will serve to support and further the work that many Indigenous women before me began: Mary Two-Axe Early, Jeannette Corbiere-Lavell, Yvonne Bedard, Sandra Lovelace, and Sharon McIvor.

For a more comprehensive analysis of this long time sex discrimination, which began with The Gradual Civilization Act, here is a peer-reviewed journal article that was published with The First Peoples Child and Family Review journal:

http://journals.sfu.ca/fpcfr/index.php/FPCFR/article/view/187

It is available as a free download. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I have additional books for sale  - both new and used - on my website.

Help get the word out about my work by reading my blogs and liking my facebook page.  Use the like and share keys, adding your own commentary, as your friends want to know what you think.

In addition, I blog and have a facebook page titled Indigenous Issues.

Chi-Miigwetch,  Lynn Gehl

story:
Hey guys, my name is Jeffrey Scott McCullough and I'm a writer for growing horror film website The Blood-Shed. We cover everything in the horror scene, but in paticular we focus on the the lesser known titles movies unknown by the general public. Stuff like Street Trash, Monsturd, along with a few more well known classics like Cannibal Holocaust; films that have been generally forgotten or neglected by the very audiences that would love it. Thats where I come in.

     With your help The Blood-Shed plans on publishing the ultimate guide to the horror movie classics that have gotten lost in the mix. The books already been started, with about a 1/3 of the entries written and all the others sketched out. With the current writing pace, the guide should be finished and ready for editing by early 2016. We currently have 3 sample chapters published online, at the links list above.

Currently, a few of the movies slated to feature include

                                                              

                                                    

                                                             Chopping Mall

                                                       

                                                  

                                                          RetarDEAD

                                                                          

                                            

                                                             C.H.U.D.

 And many more!

   Unfortunatly though, publishing a book independently isn't cheap. There are editors,artists, and writers who all need to make a paycheck. Thanks to our connections in the industry, we can publish fairly cheaply, but as with all projects there is still a steep cost. I'm already investing a significant amount of my own capital into the project, but it still won't be enough.

   That's where you come in. Were offering a ton of awesome perks, including signed copies, headshots, chances to chat with me about horror movies, and even creative input on the book.

  So, if you guys are as passionate for titles that have been rarely seen and perhaps never written about as I am, lets make this happen! And should we go beyond our goal, god bless, we have plenty of stretch goals.

$750- 5 more movies featured

$1,000- 10 more movies featured

$1250- An Awesome Cover, designed by a proffesional artist

 $1500- 20 more movies featured

$1750- Forward written by a well known star in the horror world (to be revealed if reached)

$2000- Everyone who contributes will receive an additional gift (to be revealed if reached)

Remember to spread the word guys- Thanks a bunch

We currently have 3 sample chapters published online, at the links list above.Currently, a few of the movies slated to feature include                                                                                                                                                                               Chopping Mall                                                                                                                                                                   RetarDEAD                                                                                                                                                                                   C.H.U.D. And many more!   Unfortunatly though, publishing a book independently isn't cheap. There are editors,artists, and writers who all need to make a paycheck. Thanks to our connections in the industry, we can publish fairly cheaply, but as with all projects there is still a steep cost. I'm already investing a significant amount of my own capital into the project, but it still won't be enough.   That's where you come in. Were offering a ton of awesome perks, including signed copies, headshots, chances to chat with me about horror movies, and even creative input on the book.  So, if you guys are as passionate for titles that have been rarely seen and perhaps never written about as I am, lets make this happen! And should we go beyond our goal, god bless, we have plenty of stretch goals.$750- 5 more movies featured$1,000- 10 more movies featured$1250- An Awesome Cover, designed by a proffesional artist $1500- 20 more movies featured$1750- Forward written by a well known star in the horror world (to be revealed if reached)$2000- Everyone who contributes will receive an additional gift (to be revealed if reached)Remember to spread the word guys- Thanks a bunch

story:
Short Summary

We are scriptwriters from the University of Sunderland, we are all in our final year of University and we are all working on individual projects.

Abby Maguire- Script- Feature Length Film- Escape

I'm Abby Maguire, 20 years old and originally from Darlington. I study TV and Radio production at the University of Sunderland and have worked on many different scripts and films during my time here. I have worked at Star Radio in Darlington, and helped out with Ceebies Big Day Out and Children in Need. I also directed a Zombie News program called, INN which is now nominated for a RTS award!

My Script is about a teenage boy, George who struggling with his overprotective and alcoholic mother, feeling trapped in his house he often finds it difficult to remain in reality. Falling into his over active imagination where his house transforms into a prison and his mother turns into an evil witch, he knows he must escape.

The script is a coming of age, action packed drama, with a unique style. (Rated 15)

Similar films: A Series of Unfortunate Events, Sucker Punch and Alice in Wonderland

Ellie J Mortimer - Script writing student and Freelance Artist 

 I'm Ellie, freelance artist and aspiring scriptwriter, studying Scriptwriting for Film, Television and Radio at university. From the experience I've had within the film industry, on Edgar Wright's The World's End, and Kenneth Branagh's Cinderella, I know that it's where I want my career to be. I've always loved film and being involved with the creative process, whether it be writing or drawing, is the ultimate goal for me. 

 Script - CHIPS 

 My story is a Science Fiction Drama set in the future where technology has taken over, and social networking is the only way that people communicate. Every member of the population has an electronic chip implanted into their brain which replaces computers… and reality itself. The series revolves around the character Remmy Drew, a girl in her early 20s, and her involvement with a rebel unit fighting against the mind controlling powers of the government.

Rebecca Follette- Downer- TV and Radio Student

Hi my name is Rebecca Follette-Downer,21 years old and from Aylesbury originally. Currently I am studying Radio and TV Production at the University of Sunderland. Previously I have worked as an intern for Rocky Mountain PBS during my time in the US.

My script is an hour long TV Pilot called Out of Time. It is based around a forensic psychologist, a detective and their hunt to catch a serial killer. In 2009, seven women were killed. Joshua Tanner was charged for their murders- only to be released on a technicality. After the trial, he disappered without a trace. Until now. Five years later, two bodies are found in the city. At first glance, these cases don't seem to be related. But these murders will start off a series of events that nobody could predict. Now they are running out of time and they have to hunt down a dangerous serial killer before the bodies start piling up

Sammy Barker- TV and Radio Student

Hi I'm Sammy Barker, 20 years old from Belper. I am currently studying TV and Radio Production at the University of Sunderland. I have previously worked with Amber Sound FM and on pilot for the sitcom 'Jobseekers'. 

My script is hour long self contained TV episode based around a train accident and the people involved. The story follows a mixture of characters lives before they get on the train, their journey and how they bond over the tragic accident that has brought them all together.


What we need money for:

Printing (we need to print several drafts of our scripts and two final copies, not to mention the evaluation)

Binding (our course requires us to bind our scripts when we hand them in, both final copies)

Software (Specialized software for script writing isn't cheap, and free trials only last so long)

Food (To keep us going through the writing process)

We will appreciate any donation even if its just £1!

Your donation will help us make our dissertations be the best they can be so that they can get entered into competitions and to help us pitch our ideas to the industry.

Thank you!

story:
NEW CAMPAIGN WITH NEW BENEFITS!

We want to thank everyone for the tremendous support we are receiving, but we are not finished, yet! In our original campaign, we set our goal incredibly low, since no poetry group in Utah had ever made more than a few hundred dollars via online fundraising sites. And then we reached that goal in less than two weeks! We were amazed, but we still have a long way to go if we're going to make it to Boston. In actuality, we will need a total of $5,000 to cover all the expenses. So, we've started this new campaign to avoid any confusion. Thank you for all your continued support! We love you already just for clicking on the links to get you here!!

What We're About

We are the Wasatch Wordsmiths, a small group of poets voted via poetry slam to represent outer Salt Lake City, Utah, at the 2013 National Poetry Slam.  This unique group of poets, consisting of Joseph Kyle Rogan (JoKyR), Tami Porter-Jones, DeAnn Emett, Adam Love, and Gray, are joining forces and combining their unique writing styles to make the Wasatch Front and Utah proud!  We spend all year writing, performing and competing in our community. We also volunteer and perform for other organizations throughout the year to help further causes like The Road Home, The Rape Recovery Center, Slutwalk, and more.


Now, we need your help to take our art to the next level. Help us get to Boston and compete against other teams from across the country. Help us show why the Utah poetry and art community is so phenomenal. You can help put us on the map!

What We Need & What You Get

In order to make it to nationals, we have to pay for:

  • Registration ($500)
  • Plane tickets for five people
  • Hotel room(s) in the beautiful (but expensive) city of Boston
  • Food while we’re there, so we don’t starve (we are willing to eat Ramen Noodles to make this happen)

Besides our undying loyalty and appreciation, we have set up a reward system for your donations that include chapbooks, souvenirs from Boston, and even a private show within 100 miles of Salt Lake.

NOTE: If you would like to request a specific Wordsmith to write a poem for you, or if you have any other specific requests, please leave a note in the comments section. We will do our best to honor all reasonable requests.

The Impact

This is the first time two teams from Utah will be heading to nationals. Members of the Wasatch Wordsmiths have previously represented Utah on semi-finals and finals stages at national events in the past.

While attending the National Poetry Slam, our Wordsmiths will be attending clinics and workshops to improve as writers, performers, and community organizers.  Poets who are part of the Wordsmiths have already put in a lot of time helping out the community through teaching, workshopping, community action, and a variety of other ways, and attending the National Poetry Slam will teach us effective strategies and methods for positive growth in SLC and Utah.

Other Ways You Can Help

Attend our local poetry slams in Salt Lake City, Riverton, and Ogden, as well as the U of U and Westminster.  Keep your eyes out for the various artistic events coming up, such as the Urban Arts Festival and the Utah Arts Festival. This site will be you source for updates on upcoming performances and events.  Many of us have chapbooks for sale individually, as well as an upcoming team chapbook set for release soon!
 
Share our link on your Facebook, Twitter us, Tumblr us. You can link us from this page or share this link on any social media sites: http://tinyurl.com/wasatchword

story:
I have been writing science fiction/fantasy for almost fourteen years, but 2013 is special. This year I participated in National Novel Writing Month (NaNoWriMo). Basic rules of NaNoWriMo are to write a 50,000 word novel from start to finish in the thirty days of November. This year was my first time participating, and it not only helped me to produce one of the best characters I have ever created, but also got me started in a whole new world of Paranormal Mystery fiction.

The resulting novel, The Demon Within, is the first in a long series that I am calling The AEON Files. And since I have a new book and a new series, I really want to travel across America to share my story (and hopefully inspire the next generation of writers to start writing). I plan to kick this tour off on May 1st and end it around October 31st, but it might run longer depending on how many venues I can line up. I will definitely be hitting up all sorts of cities and towns within the lower 48 states, but I am not sure about Canada, Hawaii, and Alaska at this time. And my tour will also be guest starring the YouTube Sensation and fellow author, Nick "Ulillillia" Smith.

Now, I know what you're probably thinking... "Doesn't your publisher fund your travels?" The answer is: Indeed they typically would, but I am only a self-published author at the moment, which means I don't have the backing of a big house publisher. That is why I need the help of people like you to make my dream come true. Even a donation of a single dollar will put me one step closer to getting out there and helping to inspire others. And if there are funds left over after the tour, every penny will be donated to charity.

As for obstacles... I really hope I do not run into anything bad, but I know it does happen. The main thing that I could causing any sort of problem (besides illness) would be car issues like flat tires, running out of gas, bad weather, that sort of thing. Aside from that, the only other problem would be if the book shipments did not show up on time.

Want to keep in touch with me? Find me on:
Facebook,Twitter, and www.nddragonwriter.com

story:
Le Projet:

L'objectif de Yepicaï est de promouvoir des artistes nouveaux ou émergents en Europe et en Amérique du Sud!

L'histoire commence en 2011 lorsque Yoann Purey, artiste multidisciplinaire ( photographie, graphisme, design. ), quitte Paris pour l'Amérique du Sud. Il tombe alors sous le charme de ce continent, de ses différentes cultures, de ses habitants et bien évidemment de son art et de ses artistes.

Pendant les 3 années où il y réside, il rencontre et collabore avec différents artistes. C'est lors de son retour en France pour quelques semaines qu'il réalise que le Vieux Continent connaît mal l'art sud-américain et sa vitalité.

Déjà créateur de modèles de tee-shirt en son nom, Yoann décide alors de voir plus grand et de créer une marque de tee-shirt, trait d'union entre l'Europe et l'Amérique du Sud.

Yepicaï naît donc officiellement en 2013 à Bogota où Yoann part s'installer.

El Proyecto:

¡ El objetivo de Yepicaï es promover a artistas nuevos o emergentes en Europa y en América del Sur!

La historia comienza en 2011 cuando Yoann Purey, artista multidisciplinar (la fotografía, el grafismo, el diseño.), se va de París para América del Sur. Cae entonces bajo el encanto de este continente, de sus diferentes culturas, de sus habitantes y desde luego de su arte y de sus artistas.

Durante los 3 años cuando reside allí, encuentra y colabora con diferentes artistas. Es en el momento de su vuelta a Francia para algunas semanas que comprende que el Viejo Continente conoce mal el arte sudamericano y su vitalidad.

Ya creativo de modelos de camiseta en su nombre, Yoann decide entonces ver en grande más y crear una marca de camiseta, guión entre Europa y América del Sur. 

Yepicaï oficialmente nace pues en 2013 en Bogotá dónde Yoann sale a instalarse.



Notre ambition:

L'objectif est de promouvoir des artistes en Europe et en Amérique du Sud en 2 temps:

1. En commercialisant en série limitée des tee-shirts arborant les créations du collectif Yepicaï via le site internet et via différents distributeurs en Amérique du Sud et en Europe.

2. Dans un second temps, en exposant ces artistes dans des galeries éphémères financées par les ventes.

L'idée étant d' offrir une dimension internationale aux artistes du collectif sur les 2 continents!

Nuestra ambición:

El objetivo es promover a artistas en Europa y en América del Sur en 2 tiempos:

1. Comercializando en serie limitada por las camisetas que enarbolan las creaciones del colectivo Yepicaï vía la página internet y vía los diferentes distribuidores en América del Sur y en Europa.

2. En segundo lugar, exponiendo a estos artistas en galerías efímeras financiadas por las ventas.

¡ La idea que es ofrecerles una dimensión internacional a los artistas del colectivo sobre los 2 continentes!



Notre engagement:

Notre engagement est de produire en Amérique du Sud des T-shirt fabriqués exclusivement en coton issu de l'agriculture Sud Américaine et particulièrement Colombienne.

Nuestro compromiso:

Nuestro compromiso es producir en América del Sur del Niqui fabricados exclusivamente de algodón nacida de la agricultura Meridional americana y particularmente Colombiana.



Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez:

Financé en partie par les économies de son fondateur, Yepicaï a encore besoin de votre soutien pour :

* lancer les premiers tests en usine environ une cinquantaine de t-shirts

* financer les premiers stocks

* concevoir et créer notre site internet

* à intégrer un flash code sur nos t-shirt 

Lo que necesitamos y lo que usted obtiene:

Financiado en parte por las economías de su fundador, Yepicaï todavía necesita su apoyo para:

* Lanzar las primeras pruebas en fábrica cerca de una cincuentena de niquis

* Financiar las primeras existencias

* Concebir y crear nuestra página internet

* Al integrar un flash codifica sobre nuestros niqui 



Contreparties:

Afin de vous remercier pour votre aide et votre soutien :

Pour 15$ et plus

Chaque donateur verra son nom cité sur notre site internet. 

Pour chaque participant nous offrons des prix uniques et originaux! 

Les prix vous seront livrés à votre domicile 2 semaines après la fin de la quête!

Contrapartidas:

Con el fin de agradecerse por su ayuda y su apoyo:

Para 15 dólares y más

Cada donante verá su nombre citado sobre nuestra página internet. 

¡ Para cada participante ofrecemos precios únicos y originales! 

¡ Los precios le serán entregados a su domicilio 2 semanas después de fin de la colecta!



VOUS POUVEZ NOUS AIDER AUTREMENT

Si vous n'avez pas les moyens de nous aider, toutes les autres marques de sympathie sont les bienvenues ! Parlez de Yepicaï autour de vous, sur Facebook, Twitter...

MERCI POUR VOTRE AIDE ET VOS ENCOURAGEMENTS

USTED PUEDE AYUDARNOS DE OTRO MODO

¡ Si usted no tiene los medios de ayudarnos, todas las demás marcas de simpatía son las bienvenidas! Hable de Yepicaï de alrededor de usted, sobre Facebook, Twitter...

GRACIAS POR SUYO AYUDADO Y SUS ESTÍMULOS

Pour chaque participant nous offrons des prix uniques et originaux! 
Les prix vous seront livrés à votre domicile 2 semaines après la fin de la quête!
Contrapartidas:
Con el fin de agradecerse por su ayuda y su apoyo:
Para 15 dólares y más
Cada donante verá su nombre citado sobre nuestra página internet. 
¡ Para cada participante ofrecemos precios únicos y originales! 
¡ Los precios le serán entregados a su domicilio 2 semanas después de fin de la colecta!


VOUS POUVEZ NOUS AIDER AUTREMENT
Si vous n'avez pas les moyens de nous aider, toutes les autres marques de sympathie sont les bienvenues ! Parlez de Yepicaï autour de vous, sur Facebook, Twitter...
MERCI POUR VOTRE AIDE ET VOS ENCOURAGEMENTS
USTED PUEDE AYUDARNOS DE OTRO MODO
¡ Si usted no tiene los medios de ayudarnos, todas las demás marcas de simpatía son las bienvenidas! Hable de Yepicaï de alrededor de usted, sobre Facebook, Twitter...
GRACIAS POR SUYO AYUDADO Y SUS ESTÍMULOS

story:
On March 6, 2008, my sixteen-year-old son, Avraham David, was shot to death in a terror attack while studying in the Mercaz HaRav library in Jerusalem. On that day my life changed forever.

In the first year of mourning my son, I often felt torn between the intimacy of loss and its public expression. In one tragic moment, my son had become a “martyr,” and I, a “bereaved parent.” Having already buried his body, I worried how I could ever preserve his memory under the frequently too-bright lights of public attention. Mourning Under Glass explores the tensions between memory and memorial, between private pain and public mourning. Can any of our attempts at memorial adequately recall an extinguished life? Can any give voice to the nearly ineffable pain of loss?

Mourning Under Glass has been called “a journey into the unthinkable: the baring of a soul still raw and wounded” (Jewish Action) and noted as offering “valuable human insights to readers regardless of their level of faith” (Jerusalem Post). Those who have read it have come away changed.

All proceeds from sales have always gone right back into projects aimed at perpetuating something of my son's memory (for example, the CD To You My Heart Has Spoken). I am now raising money to finish translating Mourning Under Glass  into Hebrew and publish it, so that the Israeli public can share in its honest depiction of pain, loss and memory. Your donation will not only get you a copy, but it will also enable others to explore the very real complexity of memorial. And keep the legacy of a young boy, so tragically killed by terrorists, from fading into the dark mists of the forgotten.


Read some of Mourning Under Glass and listen to some of To You My Heart Has Spoken while you make your donation!

*The fine print: Any excess funds will be utilized for further memorial projects at our discretion.

story:
Una mano por la PAZ

Ayúdanos a sanar las heridas de la violencia

Con tu contribución el Centro de Ayuda ALAPÁS continuará ofreciendo servicios a las víctimas del crimen en Puerto Rico. Lo recaudado en la campaña servirá para costear las oficinas del Centro.

Al mismo tiempo, aportas al país y garantizas nuestra presencia en la lucha contra el crimen, para que podamos continuar brindando servicios gratuitos para las víctimas, como:

  1. Terapia sicológica individual para adultos y niños, grupo de apoyo e intervenciones en crisis.
  2. Orientación legal y acompañamiento al tribunal de las víctimas.
  3. Movimiento social hacia la prevención de la violencia mediante publicaciones y charlas.
  4. Educación y empoderamiento para hacer valer los derechos de las víctimas.
  5. Movimiento a favor de legislación para apoyo de las víctimas.

 Somos:

Una organización sin fines de lucro que se constituyó en memoria de la poeta Laura Isabel Aponte Rivera, joven universitaria de 19 años, quien falleció el 22 de junio de 1997, al recibir una bala perdida mientras se encontraba en la discoteca Hollywood en el viejo San Juan. 

El objetivo principal de la organizacion es promover la justicia social aportando a la solución del grave problema de la criminalidad en la sociedad puertorriqueña mediante la creación de proyectos específicos que fomenten el análisis, la reflexión, la sanación de personas afectadas por el problema de la criminalidad y la educación transformadora.

Este objetivo se articula a través de proyectos que integran la educación, la prevención y la sanación. Destacamos el Centro de Ayuda ALAPÁS, el Bosque de los Siemprevivos, Educación y Alcance Comunitario

Centro de Ayuda ALAPÁS- Su propósito es ofrecer, en forma gratuita, apoyo, orientación y psicoterapia a la familia de las víctimas fatales de asesinato u homicidio, carjacking, accidentes automovilísticos por causa de conductor ebrio o intoxicado y por negligencia crasa al conducir.

El Centro de Ayuda ALAPÁS comenzó a ofrecer servicios a partir del 9 de enero de 2007. El Centro atiende a las víctimas desde el momento en que ocurre el delito y sin necesidad de referido, lo que facilita a la víctima acceso rápido a un servicio. El Centro brinda servicios mayormente al área metropolitana de San Juan, pero también recibe participantes de todos los pueblos de Puerto Rico.

En el Centro de Ayuda ALAPÁS ofrecemos a sobrevivientes de homicidio manejo integrado de servicios de:

  • Intervención en crisis
  • Consejería individual
  • Consejería grupal
  • Consejería telefónica
  • Orientación legal
  • Acompañamiento al tribunal
  • Intercesoría
  • Referidos

En el Centro se continúa la coordinación del Grupo de Apoyo ALAPÁS, precursor de la organización. Se reúne desde 1997. Complementa la terapia individual. En las reuniones del Grupo de Apoyo los integrantes tienen la oportunidad de expresar su sentir y sus necesidades entre personas que los comprenden porque han sufrido la misma experiencia.  Los participantes aprenden cuáles son las etapas del duelo y adquieren herramientas para lidiar con su proceso.

Bosque de los Siemprevivos - Atendiendo la sanación desde una perspectiva holística, ALAPÁS y el Departmento de Recursos Naturales y Ambientales desarrollaron este bosque en el que los familiares que perdieron seres queridos víctimas del crimen sembraron árboles en su memoria. De esta manera se armonizaron e integraron aspectos terapéuticos, educativos, sociales, ecológicos y ornamentales. 

Educación - El proyecto educativo es un mecanismo para crear conciencia sobre la violencia y los derechos humanos en el País. Uno de los medios es la Revista ALAPÁS cuyo fin es familiarizar a los puertorriqueños y puertorriqueñas sobre el manejo del dolor debido a pérdidas de seres queridos a causa de crímenes violentos. Sirve también para educar a las víctimas sobre sus derechos y para que se escuche su voz. Cabe señalar que esta es una de las muchas formas en que ALAPÁS combate la violencia y reafirma una vez más su alto sentido y dirección hacia la prevención de las conductas violentas. Esperamos tener una serie de tiradas al año, de manera electrónica y en papel.

Alcance Comunitario - se logra a través de las alianzas con instituciones, entidades y comunidades. Parte de este proyecto es Tacita de café, proyecto inspirado en el premio Solidaridad, y el Acto de Recordación de los Hijos(as) Fallecidos(as):

  • Tacita de Cafe - Proyecto de solidariad en el cual pretendemos estrechar lazos entre organizaciones con el fin de conocernos y unir esfuerzos en nuestra lucha por un mejor Puerto Rico.
  • Acto de Recordación de los Hijos(as) Fallecidos(as) - Cada año, a iniciativa de ALAPÁS, se celebra un acto de recordación para todos los(as) jóvenes fallecidos(as) durante el año por causas violentas  y, además, en memoria de nuestros hijos.  Durante el acto las familias colocan una estrella en un árbol de Navidad en memoria de su hijo o hija. Esta actividad presenta a las familias un espacio muy especial para compartir empáticamente. Esta celebración fue oficialmente reconocida mediante la aprobación de la Ley Núm. 144 de 11 de junio de 2004, según enmendada, para establecer el segundo domingo de diciembre, el “Día de Recordación de los Hijos y Familiares Fallecidos en Actos de Violencia”.

Logros:

2012 - Segunda edición del 5K Unidos por la Paz; el primero fue en 2010.

2012- Presidenta de ALAPÁS formó parte de la Junta Asesora del Comité de Revisión Curricular del Programa de BA en Sistemas de Justicia de la Universidad de Sagrado Corazón.

2011- Inauguramos el salón de terapias para niños y niñas.

2011- Reconocimiento como modelo por Hablando de Filantropía.

2010 - Premio Solidaridad: Honrando lo que nos une.

2010 - Participación con taller: La Esperanza de las Víctimas en el Torcido Camino del Derecho en el Congreso Internacional de Derecho Penal, auspiciado por El Colegio de Abogados de Puerto Rico.

2009 - Reconocimiento del Departamento de Justicia en ocasión de la Semana de los Derechos de las Víctimas.

2008 - Dedicatoria de la Asamblea Anual de la Coalición Puertorriqueña Contra la Pena de Muerte.

2008 - Prologamos el libro de la Dra. Dinorah Navarro, Un Sendero Misterioso: Apuntes para la Comprensión del Duelo y la Aflicción.

2007 - Premio Solidaridad: Honrando lo que nos une -mención honorífica.

2006 - Presidenta de ALAPÁS formó parte, por invitación, del Comité Consultivo para establecer la primera Academia para proveedores de servicios a víctimas del crimen en Puerto Rico.

2006 - Presidenta de ALAPÁS fue electa al Comité Coordinador de la Coalición Puertorriqueña Contra la Pena de Muerte.

2003 - Presidenta de ALAPÁS fue designada por la entonces gobernadora de Puerto Rico, Hon. Sila María Calderón, representante de las víctimas en la Comisión de Derechos de Víctimas de la Administración de Corrección. Formó parte del Comité hasta el año 2005.

2002 - Homenaje a Presidenta de ALAPÁS, el 8 de marzo, Día Internacional de la Mujer Trabajadora, por parte de la Cámara de Representantes.

story:
WILDERNESS+HISTORY=ADVENTURE!
 In 1963, a handful of intrepid explorers mounted mules in the border town of Tecate, Baja California, Mexico. For six months they rode south, 1000 miles through the roadless desert  of the Baja Peninsula. Two of the original ten riders arrived. Along the way they were chased by Federales and had a mountain lion eat one of their mules. They lived through temperature extremes and water shortages. They collected and catalogued plants new to science. They filmed, photographed and journalled. Yet they agreed not to publish. To date, only one article has been written about this "long ride".  50 years later, this amazing adventure-The Meling Expedition-is being ridden again, this time as La Mula Mil (The Mule 1000).

Under the consult and blessing of three of the surviving original riders: Andy Meling, Joanne Alford and Eve Ewing, three modern riders: Trudi Angell, Olivia Angell and Leslie Pringle will travel the route in reverse, riding along the El Camino Real and as many of the other original trails as possible. There are many parallels and as in the first ride, there is a 24 year old, a photographer and at times a botanist. 

Along the way we will photograph, film, Facebook, Tweet and blog.  Upon completion we will publish a large hardcover photography book about both our adventure and the Meling Expedition. In it you will meet the people and see the places in this land of contrasts. Eve, Andy and Joanne have shared their tales with us so the stories of both expeditions can be told. You'll see the land and her people as they were then and now.

Who are we? Trudi has lived and operated a tour company in Loreto, Baja California Sur for over 30 years. Her daughter Olivia has grown up there too, often accompanying her mother on rides, some up to six weeks long. Leslie, an experienced traveller in her own right, met and became fast friends with them and Eve over the last decade whilst exploring in the area. We will have guest riders for periods too, including a Biodiversity Explorer (that's really her job title!) a historian/archivist and some desert landscape artists. 

Please help prevent a piece of history from being lost and allow us to share the story by contributing to this campaign.  As a thank you we offer you a choice of authentic hand-made ropes and riding gear made from rawhide, goat hide or horsehair, books and/or videos.  And of course, our gratitude and a sense of history coming alive! 

There are marketing opportunities too.


The money raised will be used to pay for mules, burros, food, accommodation, pasture, transportation and other supplies, most of which will be rented or purchased from people living in the area.  Some areas are so remote that there aren't even ranches, so we need to organize supply drops for humans and animals. This will come to $17,000. 

Any excess funds will be divided as follows: 15% to our three favourite NGOs (non-profit associations), Coins for Classrooms, Living Roots Baja and Mujeres del Golfo, with the remainder to be used towards production of the book and video.

How can you help?

Please donate to the cause.

Please spread the word:

  • use your Facebook, Twitter or other social media sites
  • include our story in your blog
  • tell your friends

Your support helps:

  • La Mula Mil to revive and share the Meling Expedition
  • to produce a book about both expeditions and the changes time has wrought
  • to employ the inhabitants of the Baja region 
  •  to fundraise for three great, small scale, non-profit associations 

Muchas Gracias!

story:
Short Summary

I’m a graphic designer, photographer, crafter, website designer and Steampunk. My business of Candice Crafts already runs successful craft fair events throughout the year, most notably at the Deaf Trust in Doncaster. I work alongside my husband, Tony, who takes care of security and also handles the more technical aspects, such as setting up the PA system. I concentrate on the planning and then, on the day, I make sure everyone is happy and cater for any special needs.

Steampunk Doncaster aims to bring the many creative aspects of Steampunk to the notice of the wider public. The largest part of the 2 day event will be a Literary Symposium, entitled ‘Litarium’, at which authors can attend for free to promote and sell their books as well as engage in discussions and workshops with the public. We have some renowned Steampunk authors attending and will also be promoting literacy with the assistance of the local Library Service.
Allied to this will be an Art Exhibition, entitled ‘Manifestation’.  All artists will be able to exhibit for free and they will have the opportunity to sell their works – the exhibition is open to all who wish to submit work. We also have other activities planned, to make the event enjoyable for the whole family, including artists workshops, gaming, photographic tuition sessions and much more. For visitor comfort and refreshment we will have tea and cakes in abundance (a necessity for Steampunks) as well as locally brewed beer and a Temperance Bar.

We’re not asking for loads of money, just enough to provide the basic necessities for the event to run smoothly. A little help can go a long way with an event of this scale.

 

What We Need & What You Get

£1200 is what we’ve identified as being the absolute minimum we would need to run this event. This amount breaks down as follows:
£270 for a fairground organ to attend for the 2 days, which will be an important element in drawing people to the site and add to the vintage atmosphere.
£50 for printed flyers, these will be distributed in the town centre the 2 weekends prior to the event to raise awareness amongst the local population (we will be in Steampunk costume while doing this).
£240 for a feather flag and 2 banners which will promote the event in the town centre and at the venue itself over the preceding month.
£640 venue hire fee for the 2 days which includes access to free car parking for visitors.

We have an experienced Steampunk photographer joining us from Holland and bringing two of his female models in order to give photographic workshops to visitors. Perks will include free sessions with this team including image manipulation techniques. We also intend to have a range of ‘gifts’ donated by attending companies such as beer from a local micro-brewery. Many of the details are still to be confirmed, but all perks will need to be redeemed at the event itself.

Any funds raised, should there be a shortfall from the amount sought, will still go towards the running of the event, which will run. However, we may have to manage without some of the promotional elements, such as the fairground organ, which would be a massive shame.

 

The Impact

Steampunk espouses the very best in behaviour and morals and also encourages creativity in all its forms. This positivity is sadly a rare thing these days and should be encouraged wherever possible. Doncaster is an area which has been identified by the UK government as being in special need of encouragement in creative arts uptake but the government are currently failing to do anything about it – so we are. We feel that Steampunk can be the means to at least start to correct this oversight.

We have been running craft fairs in this region since 2010 and have built a reputation for customer care and fairness. This event, while differing slightly from our craft fairs, is no different in scale or logistics and we feel confident that we can provide an enjoyable atmosphere in which visitors can explore the creativity of Steampunk.

Our ambition is for this to become an annual event for Doncaster and one with which local businesses can engage. We already have the support and encouragement of the local Council and have been promised the equivalent of £5000 in support in kind from them and other agencies. Please note that ‘support in kind’ means that we receive no actual funding from these agencies.

 

More details on the ‘Litarium’…

Craig Hallam, our Literary Co-ordinator and author of ‘Greaveburn’ will be hosting a workshop entitled ‘Creating a reality in fantasy’.

Jonathan Green, author of the Pax Britannia series amongst many titles, will be hosting a workshop entitled ‘Creating characters’.

Anna Chen, performance poet and author of ‘The Opium Wars’, will be performing her works.

Moore & Reppion, creators of many graphic novels including ‘The Complete Dracula’ and ‘The Complete Alice in Wonderland’, will be hosting a workshop entitled ‘Telling your story visually’.

Rod Gillies, author of ‘Red Mercury’, and LM Cooke, author of ‘The Automata Wars’, will also be giving talks, subjects to be confirmed.

Plus, Allegra Hawksmoor of ‘Steampunk Magazine’ will be hosting a discussion entitled ‘The role of morality in Steampunk.

There will also be some creative writing competitions linked to the Litarium, for both children and adults, including a Steampunk Limerick Jam!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please do your best to spread the word about our event, not just to any Steampunks you may know, but to anyone interested in the arts or even just curious about what Steampunks look like!

Use the Indiegogo share tools as well as Facebook, Twitter and other social networking to get people to come along.
story_txt:
Short Summary
I’m a graphic designer, photographer, crafter, website designer and Steampunk. My business of Candice Crafts already runs successful craft fair events throughout the year, most notably at the Deaf Trust in Doncaster. I work alongside my husband, Tony, who takes care of security and also handles the more technical aspects, such as setting up the PA system. I concentrate on the planning and then, on the day, I make sure everyone is happy and cater for any special needs.
Steampunk Doncaster aims to bring the many creative aspects of Steampunk to the notice of the wider public. The largest part of the 2 day event will be a Literary Symposium, entitled ‘Litarium’, at which authors can attend for free to promote and sell their books as well as engage in discussions and workshops with the public. We have some renowned Steampunk authors attending and will also be promoting literacy with the assistance of the local Library Service.Allied to this will be an Art Exhibition, entitled ‘Manifestation’.  All artists will be able to exhibit for free and they will have the opportunity to sell their works – the exhibition is open to all who wish to submit work. We also have other activities planned, to make the event enjoyable for the whole family, including artists workshops, gaming, photographic tuition sessions and much more. For visitor comfort and refreshment we will have tea and cakes in abundance (a necessity for Steampunks) as well as locally brewed beer and a Temperance Bar.
We’re not asking for loads of money, just enough to provide the basic necessities for the event to run smoothly. A little help can go a long way with an event of this scale.

story:
OutBoise Magazine is a new magazine for the LGBT community in the Treasure Valley. Our first issue goes live in digital format on November 1st, with stories debuting on the website the same day. This magazine will be the first of its kind for the city of Boise and the surrounding area. 

This magazine will feature stories and photos about the local LGBT community, by members of our community. It will also feature local gay-friendly businesses, activities and organizations.

Our mission is to inspire, encourage, and educate members of our community by providing them as much information as possible about what is happening around the valley. This will include LGBT-friendly businesses and entertainment venues, community organizations they can get involved with, and inspirational stories from members of the community who are willing to share.

We want people to know what events they can be involved with, encourage them to partake in community-service opportunities, and we want to show them that Boise is not as close-minded as many believe it is.

Our website launched on August 21st and already features a number of great articles submitted by local writers, and also includes photos taken by members of our community. With over 6,000 visits to the site since it launched, we have received a lot of great feedback from the community. Our Facebook page, on average gets close to 1,800 views per week, and we're soon to launch our mobile application, which is in need of a stronger design platform.

The biggest question we've received has been: where can I pick up a copy?

Our initial goal was to print 1,000 to 1,500 copies of our magazine; however, due to high costs and lack of investors, we've had to keep things in digital-only format. We have been able to maintain our expenses for our website, and mobile app through advertising space in the magazine, but would like to expand further.

We would like to expand our reach in the community, and help spread our positive message to the rest of the Treasure Valley.

In the months to come, we want to take the magazine to print, and distribute it to locations around the valley. As of right now, we have over 20 locations around the valley who have offered to carry our publication once we are able to, and we hope to expand beyond these distribution points.

This project has been a great success already, and we're excited that our first issue will be released on the 1st. We plan to bring a new issue out on the 1st of every month, and have a special issue planned for June, when we hit our 25th anniversary of Gay Pride in Boise. We hope to have our distribution to, at least, 5,000 physical copies by then.

You can catch our first issue, here:

http://joom.ag/SxAb

story:
I have lived and worked with youth for most of my life. My experience as a counsellor and as an advocate for youth has given me insight into the developmental needs of our young people. I am the founder and director of Street Spirits, a program for youth that has transformed the lives of hundreds of youth over the past fifteen years. I hold a Master’s Degree in Education from Simon Fraser University and have won numerous awards for my work with children and youth including the Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee medal and the Canada Peace medal. I believe that we serve our children best when we foster expectations of personal and community responsibility and invite them to take a positive role in the world. 

Over the past years our schools have suffered increasing pressures to do more with diminishing resources. The wellbeing and future of our children has been turned into a political bargaining chip with little regard for the consequences. I want your help to change that. I believe that we need to recognize the uniqueness of life in the North. Costs are different and the needs of our children are different. We also live in a changing world. Think of the jobs out there right now that did not exist twenty years ago. Think of the shifting nature of our workplaces. Changes in markets and in technology mean that what our children do for a living may be very different from our experience.  We need an educational system that prepares our young people to adapt to that changing environment. Our schools need to prepare young people for lifelong learning and to be a part of strong and connected communities. We have among our school staff the people with the skills and drive to create such a system. We need a school board with the vision and the will to support the development of Twenty First Century Education. I am asking the people of our Northern communities to support me with their votes in November as a trustee for the Board of School District 57. To do that I need to reach the people. I need to engage in the conversations and address the issues. Doing so requires the funding to run a campaign. Please help to make our schools the best they can be.

Any campaign funds left after the election will be donated to charity.

Other Ways You Can Help

*Wear a button.

* Contact us to take a lawn sign for your yard.

*Volunteer to help us with the campaign.

*Share your thoughts and ideas with us.

*Share this :-)

story:
In true Little Miss Sunshine style - we are doing a road trip in a van with a beauty pageant princess from Cusco to Niagara Falls - the result an awesome book and one even greater adventure.  #andoffwewent

It started with a dream...

In July 2013 our family (Matt, Michelle, Emilia and Matthew) headed off into the great unknown - we boarded a flight from Canada to Peru, ending up in Cusco with a 3 month return ticket and a pile of suitcases. But we didn't go home. We decided that Cusco was a great place to spend some time to teach our children about worldwide traditions, other cultures - we even found ourselves participating in a beauty pageant. In February 2014 we found ourselves managing a small hostel in central Cusco, our Casa Emilia, enabling us to really embrace our crazy lifestyle.

Come March 2015, it will be time to move on and this time we are seeking another adventure. We are going to do the long drive home - from Cusco, Peru to Niagara Falls, Canada crossing the vast continent of South America, Central America and North America in a van with two awesome but quirky kids - one loves to sing and the other loves to do Michael Jackson impressions.  World-schooling, volunteering, meaningful travel and awesome adventures - and totally book worthy to boot.

About us...

Michelle is a content writer, ghostwriter and freelance journalist, focussing on the business, lifestyle and travel genres. She quite happily spends most of her time behind the scenes writing blog posts, Facebook commentary, articles and e-books on behalf of busy managers. Her first full length publication Love Alters, an anthology, will be published in January 2015. She is passionate about pursuing her dreams and enabling others to pursue their own dreams along the way.

Matt is a hotel manager and English teacher, having taught in both Peru and China. He enjoys having in-depth conversations with his students on the subject of the English language, or anyone for that matter.  He is open to English teaching and accommodation management opportunities en-route.

Emilia is a little girl with big dreams. She loves to sing, dance and eat chocolate cake. She thinks travelling is fun and is looking forward to her adventures on the road.

Matthew can't wait to visit the places he sees on the map. Up for adventure like his big sister, he is extremely sociable and loves to talk...and talk...and talk...

The book...

Our book "And Off We Went" is in the works.  Michelle is currently working on the initial chapters detailing their adventures in Cusco, Peru and how the trip came to be.  We understand that 2017 is a long way off so for those who pre-purchase a copy of the book (Lake Titicaca, Copan and Iguazu Falls perks), you will be also be given "exclusive access" to behind the scenes emails detailing our adventures. 

Our plan...

Our plan is to drive from Cusco in a VW Kombi (pictured below) heading to Lima and then moving on to Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, Brazil, Paraguay, Venezuela, Colombia and Ecuador before moving on to Central and North America.


By the way - our van won't always look like this.  We have commissioned the fabulous young artist Jocy Terrazas to create a "Jocy" original on our vehicle.  And if her Facebook page is anything to go by, you will definitely see us coming!

Meet Jocy:


We are going to share our journey with others via our travel book connecting with other world-schoolers and travellers, learning from them and sharing our combined experiences. We have partnered with GlobeDrop who promote meaningful travel by connecting travellers with NGOs allowing them to make specific donations of goods direct to the organisation - no middle man required.  We will be visiting a number of NGOs and promoting the benefits of GlobeDrop as we travel.


Michelle will be continuously working en-route while penning the book And Off We Went, and the family will be looking for volunteering, writing and teaching jobs as well as management opportunities along the way.

The why...

#1 - why not?

#2 - I want to write that book!

Michelle and Matt want to demonstrate to families all over the world that travelling with a young family is both worthwhile and possible. We hear too many stories about families waiting for their children to leave home before they travel - particularly undertaking such long journeys such as this.  But the benefits of travelling with children is well documented - we wish to raise worldwide citizens who understand the world and the way things work.

We are embracing world-schooling and meaningful travel as a way to teach and educate and there is no doubt that it will be an amazing experience for all involved.

Michelle is not new to the world of writing as she works as a ghostwriter, but she is looking forward to the challenge of creating a travel book for families under her own name and the other media opportunities that come with it.

How you will help...

While we are willing to work and volunteer along our journey, the money will enable us to ensure that our vehicle is safe to travel the distance and that we are prepared for any eventuality along the way.  Remember that this journey will take us at least 12 months to complete - with the book due for completion and publication in 2017. Your support will help Michelle find time to sit down, research, write and publish the book in between work assignments. 

In exchange for your support or donation, we can offer a variety of opportunities for you or your business.  We can send you a postcard or a souvenir from one of the many countries we will visit.  You can pre-order a copy of our book - signed or otherwise.  You can order Michelle's writing services or take up one of our corporate sponsor opportunities to be mentioned in the book and on our blog and even on our vehicle!  The choice is yours.    

Our impact...

Meaningful Travel:  Our major sponsor for the trip is an organisation called GlobeDrop.  They are a free web application that allows travellers to connect and communicate with social welfare establishments and NGOs around the world. We hope to visit many of the NGOs and social welfare organisations as we go to highlight the great work the GlobeDrop is doing for these companies all around the world.  They are working with organisations in South, Central and North America. 

Worldschooling:  There is a huge worldschooling culture out there and we would like to introduce it to the mainstream. Whether you are travelling around Australia, the States or even abroad, children from all over the world can benefit from this amazing eye opening experience.

Challenges ahead...

We are not saying that it is going to be easy - but it is certainly going to be an adventure and a lot of fun. We are sure we are going to encounter issues and problems along the way but that is what we want to learn about and highlight for other travellers looking to do a similar thing.

We appreciate your support...

We understand that not everyone is in a position to support our book or our cause. However if it is something you would like to support but are unable to assist with financially, we would appreciate you sharing it with others who may be in a position to do so, particularly corporations who would benefit in partnering up with us.  The Indiegogo sharing tools make it super easy.

You can view our other sponsors and supporters here.

We are open to opportunities as they are presented to us so get in touch if you think you can help us with an aspect of our campaign.  Let's make this happen!

Thanks for your support - Michelle, Matt, Emilia and Matthew x

#andoffwewent

story:
Short Summary

Hello everyone my name is Bert Starzer and I believe dreams come true.  During my life I've faced various struggles, non more exhaustive than growing up with A.D.D.  It wasn't until I became an adult I was able finally learn why it took me 11 years to get a 4 year Bachelors degree in creative writing non the less.  

17 years ago I just happened to cross paths with a beagle named Hershey who was in transit to yet another home.  We met completely by chance, but right from our introduction I could tell she was a special dog, having been around dogs my entire life, and I adopted her that same evening.  When I first met Hershey I could tell she had been through a variety of circumstances, but as I got to know her through the years and she faced other life issues and health issues she seemed to know if she held on for just a little bit longer everything would get better.  Hope means to desire with the expectation of obtainment.  I believe Hershey had hope and as an animal lover  I feel we can learn from all forms of life if we just take time to observe and "listen".  Hershey revealed to me that hope and perseverance are the keys to making dreams come true.  And it was that spirit that inspired me to write the Hershey the Hound of Hope Series.  

I believe this book will be an incredible tool for parents because it covers the issues of hope, friendship, love and bullying.  My desire is to share with children, youths, their parents and anyone who reads the books that hope still exists, even when it may not seem that way.  I know things don't look so great in the world today, but I do believe Hope exists and that hope and perseverance are the keys to making dreams come true.  I believe anyone who has a dream should never give up until it has come true.  That is what I want to share through the Hershey the Hound of Hope series.   

What We Need & What You Get

I need $3,500.00 for this project.

Line Editing - $194.00

Book Layout Format Design - $325.00

Cover Design - $300.00

Illustrations - $400.00 - 500.00

ISBN - $65.00

Copyright Application - $99.00

Library of Congress - $99.00

E-Book Creation - $175.00

eISBN - $50.00

Marketing and Advertising - $1,693

For everyone who gives you are helping place not only a wonderful book into the hands of children and youths, but a very valuable teaching tool that parents can use to bring up topics such as sharing, hope, bullying, friendship and love.

The Impact

I know times are tough, but I also know children and adults need hope.  Hershey was the inspiration I needed to show me that dreams come true.  I believe her story can be the same inspiration for everyone in need of hope in their lives.  By contributing you too can put the message of hope in someone's hands. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to contribute I would greatly appreciate you sharing this campaign with all of your friends, family and coworkers.  Thank you very much for all of your help in sharing the message of hope, perseverance and love.
